babbler module¶

class babbler.Babbler(n, seed=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Markov Babbler

After being trained on text from various authors, can ‘babble’, or generate random walks, and produce text that vaguely sounds like the author.

Parameters

  • n (int) – The length of an n-gram for state

  • starters (list(str)) – The list of possible starting ngrams

  • stoppers (list(str)) – The list of possible ending ngrams

  • dictionary (dict(str, list(str))) – The dictionary mapping a ngram to the list of its successors

add_sentence(sentence)[source]¶

Process the given sentence.

Parameters

sentence (str) – The string separated by spaces. The sentence is expected to be lowercase.

Variables

  • words (list(str)) – The list converted from the given sentence.

  • ngram (str) – The current ngram.

add_file(file_name)[source]¶

Process the file with the given file_name.

The method is assuming that the input data has already been pre-processed so that each sentence is on a separate line.

Parameters

file_name (str) – The name of the target file directory.

get_starters()[source]¶

Return a list of all n-grams that start any sentence the program has seen.

The resulting list may contain duplicates because one n-gram may start multiple sentences.

Return starters

The list of possible starting ngrams

Rtype starters

list(str)

get_stoppers()[source]¶

Return a list of all n-grams that stop any sentence the program has seen.

The resulting value may contain duplicates because one n-gram may stop multiple sentences.

Returns

The list of possible ending ngrams

Return type

list(str)

get_successors(ngram)[source]¶

Return a list of words that may follow the given n-gram. If the given state never occurs, return an empty list.

The resulting list may contain duplicates, because each n-gram may be followed by different words.

For example, suppose an author has the following sentences: ‘the dog dances quickly’ ‘the dog dances with the cat’ ‘the dog dances with me’

If n=3, then the n-gram ‘the dog dances’ is followed by ‘quickly’ one time, and ‘with’ two times.

Parameters

ngram (str) – The ngram to search its successors

Returns

The list of words that may follow the given n-gram.

Return type

list(str)

get_all_ngrams()[source]¶

Return all the possible n-grams that the program has seen across all sentences.

Returns

All the possible n-grams

Return type

dictionary view object

has_successor(ngram)[source]¶

Return True if the given ngram has at least one possible successor word, and False if it does not.

Parameters

ngram (str) – The ngram to search if its successors exist or not

Returns

If the give ngram has at least one successor

Return type

bool

get_random_successor(ngram)[source]¶

Given an n-gram, randomly pick from the possible words that could follow that n-gram.

The randomness should take into account how likely a word is to follow the given n-gram. For example, if n=3 and the program is train on these three sentences: ‘the dog dances quickly’ ‘the dog dances with the cat’ ‘the dog dances with me’ and get_random_next_word() is called for the state ‘the dog dances’, the program returns ‘quickly’ about 1/3 of the time, and ‘with’ 2/3 of the time.

Parameters

ngram (str) – The ngram to get its random successor

Returns

The randomly selected word that could follow the given ngram

Return type

str
